intro: Melandrium scopulorum, commonly known as the rock catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the rocky and sandy soils of Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family, which includes other familiar plants like carnations and pinks. The plant is characterized by its upright stems and clusters of small, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are narrow and linear, often covered in fine hairs, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous tiny seeds. Melandrium scopulorum is adapted to thrive in harsh, well-drained environments, making it a resilient species in its native habitats.
